text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new mega death
album the sick the dying and the dead
this is the 16th full-length studio
album from thrash metal legends mega
death generally speaking what can be
said about mega death that hasn't been
said a million times already not much
yeah they're one of the big four thrash
metal bands with some of the most
hard-hitting and influential records in
the genre under their belts but it's
also been so many years and lineup
changes since those old days the band is
essentially dave mustain and friends at
this point add on top of that the 2010s
weren't exactly a pretty time in the
band's discography and i went into this
new lp
not expecting much better especially
with the sick the dying and the dead
already being a ridiculous title i mean
the sick and the dying is pretty
redundant as i imagine uh that the sick
are so sick they're close to if not
dying i don't think dave would like pick
up the pen
if it was him or someone else who was
just i don't know kind of suffering from
a sinus infection and the dying and the
dead so basically dead people and people
who are on their way to being dead
people bring out your dead like i i get
it but uh it mostly seems like a lot of
distinctions without a difference which
is kind of how this record sits in
megadeth's current discography now i
will give it to dave and kiko some of
the guitar mixes on this lp are heavy
chunky the solo work is insane too and
vocally dave seems to have mostly
bounced back from his bout with throat
cancer a few years ago though personally
i'll say that he's never been one of my
favorite thrash vocalists his gruff talk
singing style has never done that much
for me not as much as tomorrow's wild
growls or even james hetfield's very
melodic roars i would say dave is mostly
up to his usual standards as far as what
we have been hearing on recent mega
death lps outside of a few moments where
he just doesn't seem to care about being
on key at all like with the track
sacrifice now is the vocal performance
on the song a result of some kind of
difficulty could be but i think this
song was worth doing another take at
least to get it up to the standards of
the singing on the other songs on the
record like life in hell which is more
than passable by modern megadeth vocal
performance standards plus i think the
age in dave's voice actually benefits
him at some points on this lp like
during the whispered vocal passages on
the opening title track of the record
which are legitimately chilling though i
do find these spoken word bits on life
in hell to be way too long-winded even
if i do appreciate the track's
commentary on selfishness and egoism
being a pathway into hell in a way the
track celebitant takes that commentary
even further with a deep dive into fame
and obsession with it with an even
better chorus dave's knack for grim
dystopian history lace storytelling also
comes out on the track dogs of chernobyl
which opens up with some really
cinematic acoustic passages and
radiation detectors clicking away it's
really good but also sounds like
something from the the black album still
i do love the chugging thrash riffs on
this cut as well as the six slide
guitars the sinister chord progression
on the hook is great too add on to that
the gruesome depictions of hair falling
out and skin burning so yeah there are
some moments on this lp that i think are
on point but there are many others that
come across very awkward weird or a bit
too campy the song nightstalkers for
example is the riff on this track sick
yeah but not so sick i want to hear dave
poetically jerk off to images of uh
american
military operations being done at night
even grosser is when ice t comes in for
this like shouted word bit where he's
like making mentions of uh night vision
and black hawk helicopters there's a lot
of great metal and especially thrash
metal tracks throughout the history of
the genre about war and the hell of war
but this is not one of them we kind of
get the same military machismo bs with
the song soldier on which in one line
does acknowledge mankind destroying
itself through war but the whole track
still reads like more of a glorification
than a condemnation as it kind of seems
like the protagonist's answer to all of
this chaos and emotional misery is just
to soldier on also on the back end of
the record we have mission to mars which
is really just a plain old boring hair
metal song masquerading as something
heavier with a
really distorted and saturated mix
honestly i would prefer a sentimental
and lovesick ballad over hearing uh dave
mustaine belchout lyrics about wanting
to be an astronaut and kind of turning
that into a needlessly grim thing and
another head scratcher on the lp has to
be the song junkie the odd thing about
this track is the plain and
matter-of-fact way that dave has when it
comes to writing about this topic the
man has literally struggled with
addiction in his lifetime in a very life
or death way and he sings about it in a
fashion that feels just
disconnected and kind of dehumanizing i
guess the point is to be gruesome and
not that this track couldn't be that but
given dave's knowledge and perspective
you'd think he could write more
substantively about this topic but
instead what we get here is something
that isn't really much beyond what you
would expect from an edgy 16 year old
pending something about this the closing
track on the record will be back because
not too bad kind of sounds like a
motorhead song on steroids the tempo
upped slightly the solo work given a
speed metal intensity again it's a kind
of righteous and badass finish to the
whole lp however i would be remiss if i
didn't mention the bonus track covers on
this thing one of which is a pumped up
version of dead kennedy's police truck
yes the ultimate hardcore punk satire of
police brutality is on this lp that also
has tracks that are like just uh getting
all hot and bothered over american
military might
is a mega death a cab now make it make
sense so that's kind of the record in a
nutshell there are a few highlights but
there are almost twice as many tracks i
am repulsed by sonically and narratively
it doesn't really add that much to
megadeth's overall catalog but i can't
be surprised given the somewhat
nihilistic attitude of many of the
tracks here feeling a strong three to a
light four on this one transition have
you given this lp a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head is another video for you to
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
megadeth
forever
